message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on psychology for help. The given situation is an example of classical conditioning, where the sound of the flushing toilet acts as a conditional stimulus that elicits a reflexive response (jumping back) similar to an unconditioned response (jumping back from hot water). White coat syndrome is also an example of classical conditioning, where the sight of a white lab coat acts as a conditional stimulus that elicits a conditioned response (anxiety) even in the absence of an actual threat. The other options are examples of operant conditioning, where a behavior is strengthened or weakened based on consequences.

We refer to the definition of classical conditioning provided by Psychology Today. The process detailed in the question is an example of classical conditioning, where the sound of the flushing toilet (neutral stimulus) becomes associated with the experience of hot water (unconditioned stimulus), leading to a conditioned response (jumping out of the way of the water). Similarly, white coat syndrome is an example of classical conditioning, where the sight of a white lab coat (neutral stimulus) becomes associated with negative experiences such as pain or fear (unconditioned stimulus), leading to a conditioned response (anxiety or fear). The other options describe operant conditioning (checking pay telephones for change after finding it previously), punishment avoidance (child not throwing tantrums to avoid being grounded), and avoidance conditioning (mouse pressing a red button to avoid receiving shocks).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on psychology for help. The scenario described in the question is an example of classical conditioning, where a neutral stimulus (flushing toilet sound) becomes associated with an unconditioned stimulus (hot water in shower) to evoke a conditioned response (jumping back from water). Among the options, only White coat syndrome involves the association of a neutral stimulus (white coat) with an unconditioned response (anxiety) to evoke a conditioned response (anxiety at the sight of a white lab coat).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on psychology for help. The conditioning process in the scenario is classical conditioning, where a stimuli (flushing toilet sound) becomes associated with a response (jumping out of the way of hot water) even in the absence of the actual stimuli. Option (D) is most similar because it also involves a learned response to a stimuli, in this case the sight of a white lab coat causing patient anxiety even though the white coat has no direct impact on their health or treatment. This is also a form of classical conditioning. The other options are examples of operant conditioning.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on psychology for help. The described situation is an example of classical conditioning, in which a reflexive behavior is triggered by a previously neutral stimulus that becomes associated with an event that evokes a natural response. Option D, white coat syndrome, also involves classical conditioning in which a patient experiences anxiety at the sight of a white lab coat due to previous negative experiences associated with medical professionals. Options A, B, and C describe operant conditioning, in which behavior is modified by rewards and punishments rather than through association of stimuli.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on classical conditioning for help. The scenario described is an example of classical conditioning, where the sound of the flushing toilet serves as the conditioned stimulus that elicits the reflexive behavior of jumping back, which has become the conditioned response. Among the options, White coat syndrome is the most similar as it involves a conditioned response (anxiety) to a conditioned stimulus (the sight of a white lab coat). The other options are examples of operant conditioning.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on psychology for help. The conditioning process detailed in the question is classical conditioning, which involves a previously neutral stimulus (sound of flushing toilet) becoming associated with an unconditioned stimulus (hot water in shower), leading to a conditioned response (jumping back from water). The closest option is (D) white coat syndrome, where the sight of a white lab coat (previously neutral stimulus) becomes associated with medical procedures (unconditioned stimulus) leading to a conditioned response of anxiety. The other options involve operant conditioning or different types of learning.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on psychology for help. The described situation is a classical conditioning process, where the sound of the flushing toilet is the conditioned stimulus, the reflexive jump back from the water is the conditioned response, and the water becoming hot is the unconditioned stimulus. Option D, white coat syndrome, is the most similar as it is a type of classical conditioning in which patients develop anxiety when they see a white coat because it has become associated with medical procedures and bad news.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on psychology for help. The scenario described is an example of classical conditioning, where the sound of the flushing toilet acts as a conditioned stimulus that produces a reflexive response of jumping back from the water, which is the conditioned response. Option D, white coat syndrome, is a similar example of classical conditioning, where the sight of the white lab coat acts as the conditioned stimulus that produces a physiological response of increased blood pressure or heart rate, which is the conditioned response. The other options are examples of other types of learning or behavior.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on psychology for help. The scenario describes classical conditioning, where a neutral stimulus (sound of flushing toilet) becomes associated with an unconditioned stimulus (hot water), triggering a conditioned response (jumping back from water). Option D, white coat syndrome, also involves classical conditioning where the white coat is a previously neutral stimulus that becomes associated with a negative response, causing anxiety in patients. Option A describes operant conditioning, option B is an example of negative reinforcement, and option C involves avoidance learning.
